giant-impact.title: PLANETARY: Moon-forming Giant Impact
giant-impact.subtitle: Understanding the evidence and long-term consequences of the last major accretion of Earth.
giant-impact.content: Earth’s evolution began 4.5 billion years ago with the Moon-forming impact between Earth and the hypothesized planet Theia. We explore whether continental-scale seismic anomalies are remnants of Theia’s mantle and how plumes from them may have triggered the earliest subduction.

sections.title: Research Questions
sections.content: Where is the missing impactor, Theia? What were the long-term tectonic consequences of the Giant Impact? Why is Earth unique in sustaining plate tectonics?

sections.title: Methodology
sections.content: We pioneered the integration of short-timescale (hour-scale) Moon-forming impact simulations with long-timescale (billion-year) mantle convection models, linking them through thermodynamic and seismic constraints. This framework enables us to connect energetic early impacts with the long-term evolution of Earth’s mantle. In addition, we employ fully 3D thermo-elasto-mechanical models to simulate deep mantle structure, plume generation, and plume-driven subduction in a self-consistent way.

sections.title: Key Findings
sections.content: 1. Our canonical Moon-forming giant impact simulations show that the collision would have melted the upper half of Earth’s mantle. 2. Mantle convection models suggest that Theia’s material sank into the lower mantle, forming the Large Low Shear Velocity Provinces (LLSVPs) over 4.5 billion years. 3. Plumes from this reservoir may have triggered the earliest subduction, offering new clues to the Moon’s origin, mantle heterogeneities, and plate tectonics.

ai-thermodynamics.title: GEOPHYSICS: AI-powered Geodynamics
ai-thermodynamics.subtitle: Mechanisms and Processes of Subduction Zone Formation
ai-thermodynamics.content: Bridging mantle flow and thermodynamics efficiently remains a major challenge. To address this, we introduce a flexible, general, and efficient framework that integrates geodynamics with thermodynamics using machine learning.

sections.title: Research Focus
sections.content: We study the conditions and processes that lead to the formation of new subduction zones, combining field observations, laboratory experiments, and numerical modeling to understand this fundamental tectonic process.

sections.title: Analytical Approaches
sections.content: Our research employs multi-scale modeling approaches, from local stress field analysis to global geodynamic simulations, to understand the initiation and early evolution of subduction systems.

images.caption: Geological processes on Mars provide insights into subduction initiation mechanisms

Mars.title: PLANETARY: Mars Dynamics
Mars.subtitle: Co-evolition of Martian interior and surface geological features
Mars.content: The internal structure of Mars, including its core, mantle, and crust, holds the key to explaining the planet’s hemispheric dichotomy and its long-term thermal evolution. Insights from marsquakes recorded by NASA’s InSight mission are reshaping our understanding of how these deep processes connect to surface geology and the planet’s divergent evolutionary path compared to Earth.

sections.title: Morphological Analysis
sections.content: We analyze seismic tomography data to characterize the three-dimensional structure and morphology of LLSVPs, identifying key differences between the African and Pacific provinces.

llsvp-ulvz.title: GEOPHYSICS: Mantle Heterogeneities
llsvp-ulvz.subtitle: Dynamics of Large Low Shear Velocity Provinces and Ultra-low Velocity Provinces
llsvp-ulvz.content: The structure, morphology, and evolution of deep mantle heterogeneities hold the key to understanding the dynamic processes operating in Earth’s interior, processes that influence the geodynamo, the supercontinent cycle, and supervolcano eruptions

sections.title: Analytical Techniques
sections.content: We employ high-precision mass spectrometry to measure lithium isotope ratios in humite group minerals, developing new analytical protocols for small sample sizes.

tectonic-magmatism.title: GEOCHEMISTRY: Tectonic Magmatism
tectonic-magmatism.subtitle: Magmatic Processes in the Bushveld Complex
tectonic-magmatism.content: Tectonic magmatism is a primary window into mantle–crust interactions, recording how melts ascend, react, and reshape the lithosphere. The differentiation of these magmas generates the chemical diversity of Earth’s crust and preserves vital clues about mantle source processes and tectonic environments.

sections.title: Petrological Analysis
sections.content: We study the textural and chemical characteristics of Bushveld rocks to understand the processes of mush emplacement and differentiation in large magmatic systems.

images.caption: Complex fluid dynamics similar to magmatic mush emplacement processes

magmatic_process.title: PETROLOGY: Ore-forming Magma Chamber Processes
magmatic_process.subtitle: Temporal Constraints from Zircon Corona Textures
magmatic_process.content: Understanding their origin, the physical and chemical processes within magma chambers, and their tectonic context not only advances fundamental igneous petrology but also informs the exploration of critical mineral resources essential for modern technology and the global energy transition.

sections.title: Geochronological Methods
sections.content: We use high-resolution ion microprobe techniques to date zircon coronas, providing precise temporal constraints on the formation and evolution of Fe-Ti oxide-bearing assemblages.

sections.title: Textural Analysis
sections.content: Detailed petrographic and electron microscopy studies reveal the complex relationships between zircon coronas and their host Fe-Ti oxides, informing our geochronological interpretations.
